interpretation_summary: The replication followed the preregistered plan closely: the Python script reconstructed the Stata analysis that underlies Panel A, Table 2 in Cohen et al. (2015). After a small path-correction, the code ran inside a Docker container and produced an OLS estimate of the effect of receiving any ACT subsidy voucher on ACT take-up. The coefficient on act_subsidy is +0.508 (SE = 0.045, p < 0.001) with household-clustered standard errors. This matches the original direction (positive) and statistical significance (p < 0.01) but is substantively larger than the published estimate of +0.187 (SE = 0.038). All specified covariates, clustering, and strata fixed effects were included, so methodological fidelity is high; differences in analytic subsample (post-baseline CHW-tested episodes, N ≈ 493) likely explain the larger point estimate. Overall, the replication supports the qualitative claim that ACT subsidies induce ACT take-up, but diverges in magnitude.

fidelity_assessment.method_alignment: Full alignment: The executed script used OLS with household-clustered SEs, included the preregistered covariates and C(cu_code) fixed effects, and applied the planned subsample filters (wave ≠ 0 and maltest_where = 1).

deviations.issue_description: File-path adjustment inside the replication script to make the data load relative instead of absolute.
deviations.impact: Low: purely technical; no effect on estimation.

deviations.issue_description: Analytic sample (post-baseline CHW-tested episodes) is narrower than the sample underlying the original 0.187 coefficient, which pooled all first illness episodes.
deviations.impact: Moderate: likely drives the larger coefficient magnitude, but direction and significance unaffected.

results_comparison.hypothesis_tested: Households that receive any ACT subsidy voucher are more likely to take ACT (drugs_taken_AL = 1) than households that receive no ACT subsidy voucher.
results_comparison.original_results: Coefficient on Any ACT subsidy = 0.187, SE = 0.038, p < 0.01 (robust household-clustered SEs); positive and significant.
results_comparison.replication_results: Coefficient on act_subsidy = 0.508, SE = 0.045, 95% CI [0.419, 0.596], p < 0.001; positive and significant. Model R² = 0.458, N = 493.
results_comparison.overall_answer: Yes: replication meets preregistered criteria (positive and p < 0.05), though effect size is considerably larger.

replication_report: Replication successful in qualitative terms: receiving an ACT subsidy markedly increases ACT take-up, with statistical significance stronger than in the original study, albeit with a larger point estimate likely due to sample restrictions.

failure_handling.suggestions: Ensure relative paths are used in scripts or mount data root consistently to avoid FileNotFound errors during container runs.
Document and justify any analytic-sample differences up front; provide sensitivity checks that replicate the exact original sample definition where possible.

notes: Magnitude discrepancy indicates sensitivity to sample definition and potential selection in CHW-tested episodes. Future work could rerun using the full first-episode sample to match the 0.187 benchmark and conduct robustness checks across waves.
